description: Borrowed from French macabre, whose etymology is uncertain. Possibly from the term danse macabre, most commonly believed to be from corruption of the biblical name Maccabees; compare Latin Chorea Machabaeorum.
Another theory derives the French term (through Spanish macabro) from Arabic مَقَابِر‎ (maqābir, “cemeteries”), plural of مَقْبَرَة‎ (maqbara) or مَقْبُرَة‎ (maqbura).

adjectives.description: macabre (comparative more macabre, superlative most macabre)

entries.meaning: Obsessed with death or the gruesome.
